comments.author: Anonymous

description.text: I used @holgero design and made it one piece so it didn't have to be put together. To be used with the Croc Rivet Part I made earlier.
A simple way to connect rods of different widths to each other. I included a few for 1/4inch dowel rods, and will work on a few more here shortly.

The minimum shell is a feature not yet implemented

Once it gets implemented it will limit how skinny you can make a connection

About the inner diameter:

What your designing is an n-sided polygon, so it is not a perfect circle, and thus you need to include a little tolerance for it to fit easily.

title: Arduino 2WD smartcar motor and sensors shield

description.text:
This is ongoing project.
I am designing Arduino shield for 2WD smartcar like this
The purpose is to create shield that will allow easy connection of sensors and control of two motors including feedback from motor speed sensors like this.

I am planning to use:

  1. Two motors ebay or from pololu
  2. Three HC-SR04 ultrasonic distance measuring sensors
  3. Photoresistor for light measurement. Something like this
  4. Possible two Sharp infrared distance measuring sensors.
  5. Two motor speed photoelectric sensors.

Shield includes ATmega328 controller for motors control. Because I want to control motors using speed feedback from motor speed sensors, I think it will be good to have dedicated controller for this task. The idea is that main Arduino board will only need to transfer desired speed for each motor via I2C. Then controller located on shield will control motors using feedback from speed sensors.

PCB was manufactured using PCBWay service (10$). Gerber files attached.

Any comments welcomed.

Motor driver

ALLEGRO MICROSYSTEMS A4973SB-T chip was selected to drive motors.
This chip has FET driving transistors, so low voltage drop expected, especially for low current motors, and minimum power will be wasted. Chip allows constant motor current up to 1.5A and voltage 5V to 50V. In my case i need 120mA and 5-6V.
Driver "ON" resistance is less then 1.5 ohm So fot 1A current voltage drop can be up to 1.5V. In my case as I need only 120mA, so voltage drop will be less then 180mV
According to SPEC DIP package can dissipate near 3W, so actually it seems possible to draw constantly up to 1A. Chis chip also has thermal protection and current limiting function.

Current limiting

I added option to use current limiting option of driver. R2,R9 0.47Ohm resistors used for current sensing. At least 0.5W resistors should be used to withstand motor stall and short circuit current.
TEXAS INSTRUMENTS LM385LP-1-2 Voltage Reference used to create 1.235V reference voltage. Current limit is 1.235/(2*0.47)=1.3A This is generally for short circuit protection as selected motor should have stall current less then 1A.
R3,C8 and R7,C7 recommended value used for current limiting.

Current sensing

R2,R9 current sensing resistors connected to A0,A1 analog inputs to enable motor current measurement and detection of stall. It may be useful to shutdown motors if stall detected and will prevent fast discharge of battery. 1.235V reference voltage also connected to AREF input of controller to improve accuracy of current measurement.

Connectors

JP1 - FDTI connector for programming ATmega328 controller
E1,E2 motor connectors
PWR - motors power generally can be 5V to 50V. For my motors 5V to 6V
S1,S2,S3 connectors for HC-SR04 sensors.
JP2 - jumper allows to power shield from FDTI connector (for initial debug)
IR1,IR2 - connectors for IR distance sensors
SS1,SS2 connectors for motor speed sensors
LIGHT - connector for light sensor
BAT - battery connector. This used to monitor battery voltage.
JP3 - jumper allows to connect voltage from PWR connector to Vin pin of Arduino

Pins used

D2-D7 pins used for HC-SR04 sensors
A4,A5 I2C communication
A3,A2 optional IR sensors
A1 optional light sensor
A0 optional battery voltage control

PCB was manufactured using PCBWay service Parts list

ALLEGRO MICROSYSTEMS A4973SB-T x2 (5$)
CRYSTAL, 32.768KHZ, 12.5PF x1 (1$)
ATmega328 with Arduino Optiboot (Uno) x2 (11$)
Ceramic Capacitor, 22 pF x2
Ceramic Capacitor, 470 pF x2
Ceramic Capacitor, 100 nF x6
Electrolytic Capacitor 100 µF x3 (1$)
Resistor 10 kOhm 0.25W - x5
Resistor 4.7 kOhm 0.25W - x2
Resistor 0.47 Ohm 0.5W - x2
DIP Socket, 16 Contacts x2
DIP Socket, 28 Contacts
LM385LP-1-2 Voltage Reference x1

title: Tricopter: center twist style (with solidworks source)

description.text:
Have you designed a tricopter, engineered a way to mount the rear servo to control yaw, then realized it's difficult to balance because of the heavy cantilevered servo and mount? I have. (check out my other projects)
This 3d-printed tricopter design moves the servo to the center and rotates the entire rear motor beam. Easy to print, easy to mount motors, easy to fly. 
I uploaded the solidworks source files too if you need to modify them to fit your servos or beams.

description.text:
I liked the belt securing design from the i3 Reworked but it was only supplied as a STL, and my preferred 3D is openSCAD.

So I reversed engineered it and scripted the belt suring design in openSCAD (attached).

I then used it from making my CobbleBOT Y-plate mounting, which was way better then the vendor provided solution(ugh).

I printed my in PLA, but mostlikely will change to ABS and or Casting in Aluminium at some point.

K8200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

.2mm

70%

description.text:
This is a basic ring gear with 54 teeth, set at 1/8" spacing. I made the hub to fit a standard 1/4" shaft on the ring gear. The pinion gear has a 1/8" shaft hole and 10 teeth.

I did not include any shaft lock recess, such as a key slot or flat or set screw holes in order to let you design your own into it. For precision, I usually bore out my shaft holes and either machine from aluminum or 3D print a new custom shaft hub designed to fit my motor output shaft and just glue or screw it into the gear model. So, the axel holes are more or less just centering holes, although they will accept standard shaft sizes as is.

My purpose for this gear arrangement is to move the bulk of the motor drive above the large wheel axel. This gear set was originally designed in order to move the wheel motor above the drive wheel axel for ground clearance. This was for a heavy duty rock crawler/ATV rover I built.

There is a disadvantage, however; dirt and debris can collect inside the gear and cause problems. Thus I made the gears rather coarse and over sized to pretty much tolerate sand and such. Still, pebbles and sticks can get in there if you are not careful.

The gear ratio is 5.4 to 1, so it is pretty low for really great torque, especially if the drive motor is a geared DC of something like 200:1. The ring gear can also work great as a turret rotator for a crane or model tank or battle ship. The over all diameter of the large gear as presented is 2.4" and the overall diameter of the pinion gear is .46".

Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.15 mm

Infill:

none

Notes:

I use PLA filament, bed temp 50C and .35 nozzle at 215C.

Gearmaker to Autocad to Cubify Design to Simplify

I use a fantastic gear making program called Gearmaker. This little gear making engine is fantastic. It lets you create any gear and exports a DXF which I then import intoAutocad and convert the drawing lines to polylines, This is very important or Cubify simply can not handle all the information. I then clean the drawing, and export to Cubify Design and build the 3D STL file, For printing, I have the standard Simplify 3D that feeds the STL info to my printer.

description.text: This was based on Eccentric Sphere Gears (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6499). I modified the SCAD files so that it would use pins instead of screws to secure the gears to the center piece and instead of a sphere a icosahedron is used. Also, this one is not eccentric so that the gears spin without the object dramatically changing shape. The STL files are already plated for printing (it can be done in 3 prints). All individual pieces are now available (all sans 'ichedron') - for single prints. Thank you Andychn for noting the importance of including those. Note the reason for the different colors in the picture are due to running out of the green plastic mid-print and having to insert white filament in it's place (by feeding it into the extruder as the green filament was fully consumed).

author: JasonGarf

title: 3DR Solo gimbal adapter for pocket camera

description.text:
Warning! If you use this, Solo and gimbal warranties will be void! Use at your own risk!

This is add-on to Solo gimbal. With this it is possible to use almost any light pocket camera. In picture there is Canon Powershot S100.
It is not necessary to make any modifications to Solo or gimbal.
Switching cameras takes only about 5 minutes

Most important thing is to do balancing very carefully. When Solo power is off and camera power on, set gimbal to level. It should stay exactly in level, no turning to any direction. If you turn gimbal to any position, it should stay there.

After every flight touch gimbals all 3 motors with fingers, are motors hot? They must be cool.
Test also Solos 4 motors, they should not be hot. They are probably warm, but may not be hot.
Test also battery. I may be warm but not hot.
If battery or any of the 7 motors are hot, stop flying immediately, and try to find error.

Parts list
  • 3D-printed parts. There is one stand for Canon S100, and one for other cameras, select one
  • 6pcs M3 x 10 mm screws
  • 6pcs M3 nuts
  • 1 camera screw, 1/4 inch, thread length about 8 mm
  • 1psc M10 x 70 mm full thread bolt
  • Several M10 nuts, washers, springs and other weight material

Probably you need also leg extensions. In Thingiverse there are several models, for example here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1521835

Instructions
  • I have printed parts with normal settings: layer height 0,3mm, infill 30%
  • Drill holes open with 3mm drill, and camera screw hole with 6,5 mm drill. Clean nut spaces
  • With gimbal you get small weights to balance different Gopro models. Fix 2,7 g weight to upper connection place. Remove possible other weights
  • Remove green clip (1 screw)
  • Test that base part will fit to Gopros place. May need some light work, use knife or file
  • Put nuts to their places.
  • Two nuts will be covered by camera stand, I have put there also some paper etc, so nuts stay in their place
  • Fix camera stand to base with 4 screws, Camera center of gravity should be in the middle of the base part, there are marks.
  • If you use other camera than Canon S100: Put camera to desired place. Measure camera screw place, and drill hole with 6,5 mm drill.
  • Turn camera part face down. Install arm to gimbal. The hole should fit to 2,7 g weight. It may need some fine tuning with knife or file.
  • Fix arm with 2 screws
  • Put hdmi cable to hole
  • Put felt pad sticker between camera and stand
  • Install camera

Removing:

  • Remove camera
  • Remove hdmi cable
  • Remove 2 screws
  • Turn camera face down. Open clip in the bottom, remove arm
  • Remove base
  • Install green camera clip
  • Install possible original balance weights
  • Install Gopro
Balancing
  • Fix camera to gimbal with camera screw.
  • Turn Solo off. Turn camera on, lens must come out. Use exactly the same camera settings as you are planning to use in photography.
  • Put 10 mm bolt to balancing hole. Add there nuts, washers, springs, wires etc, until camera is balanced in left/right direction. You have 3D-printer, so you can also make your own light weights from plastic :-)
  • Then move that bolt forward or backward, until the camera is balanced in front/back direction.
  • Turn camera face down. It should stay there. If it turns to some direction, then you must take camera off, loosen those 4 screws, and adjust camera stand to right position. Probably you must make several adjustings until the camera is in right position.
  • Check that this bolt does not touch props in any position
  • Set gimbal to level. It should stay exactly in level, no turning to any direction. If you turn gimbal to any position, it should stay there.
  • If you are taking ortophotos (camera straight down), check that balance arm has free space to move. May need to use shorter balance screw?
  • Propellers air flow hit to the arm. Is some kind of air cover needed?
  • In the beginning make only short flights, and after flight test that gimbal motors are cool. They may not be hot.
Flight
  • Use low speed
  • Do not make fast turns
  • Do not fly in strong winds
  • After every flight test motor temperatures (7 motors) They may not be hot.
Warnings
  • Use this at your own risk!
  • Probably there is no gimbal repairing service, if you break something, you need to buy new gimbal.
  • Gimbal motors are designed for light Gopro. Now there is about 300g more weight, admittedly well balanced. Gimbal warranty will be void.
  • No modifications to Solo are needed. All connectors are original, so they are according to the specifications. Gimbal and camera (Canon S100) weight is about 570g. This is more than payload capacity 500g, which is mentioned in manual. In Solo development guide there is text, that gimbal recommended weight is 390g, but maximum allowed payload weight 700g. In this system weight is near the front props, not in the middle. This gimbal adapter is not officially accepted by 3DR, so Solo warranty will be void.
  • Solo motors must work harder. In motors there may be hidden fault in wires or poor soldering. In normal use they work, but now these may come out, and cause crash. Look the last picture.
FAQ
  • Yes, it is a gimbal for Canon Powershot S100 and almost any other pocket size camera!
  • Yes, it works. You can adjust camera with same controls as Gopro. Solo keeps horizon level
  • No, you can not trigger camera remotely. I have used CHDK and time lapse, that takes pictures at 3 second intervals
  • No, you can not see live video from this camera. Canon cameras has HDMI, but with it you can only look pictures from memory card. It is possible to use av2hdmi converter, and it works (This is in one of the pictures above). Picture goes black every time when the camera takes photo, but anyway you can adjust camera with it. Here is the adapter for HDMI converter: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2072116
  • Yes, this is for taking photos. Heavy camera has tendency to jitter, and videos are not stable. But photos are good. Only 2 - 5 out of 1000 photos are shaken. I continue testing with other rubber absorbers
  • Yes, you can make for example multipoint cable cam route with Gopro, change camera, and fly again, and camera turns as Gopro
  • Yes, in orbit and some other flight modes Solo turns camera according to flight plan
  • Yes, it works also in Tower app. The default flight speed is too fast for this 3 seconds interval, you must use slower speed
  • Yes, I have tested it during tens of flights, several flight hours, tested about 100 cable cams, orbits, selfies, Tower, taken more than 2000 pictures
  • Yes, you can take georeferenced stabilized ortophotos (camera straight down). This Canon model has gps
  • Yes, probably you can use almost any other light camera, that weights less than about 200g. And also flirs, cellphones and action cameras
  • Yes, the camera is bigger, so in heavy wind and in fast speed it may have difficulties to keep camera steady and in target
  • No, probably this does not fit to backpack, camera is bigger than Gopro. Some cutting is needed? I have not tested, I don't have backpack.
  • Total weight (camera + gimbal) is about 570g, so it is more than official payload capacity 500g mentioned in manual. Solo warranty will be void.
  • Flight time is about 10 - 11 minutes (15% battery left)
  • Official Solo gimbal specifications: http://dev.3dr.com/hardware-gimbalbay.html

Replace old filament feed mechanism on your Up! with this one, using the same bolt. Slip filament through slot, and you're good to go.

This mask is a tool for people to keep quiet and hide from the rest when they want to. As a part of this world, communication is essential, especially as a student in art school, apart from making art projects, communication is everything in this education system. However, there is always moments that you do not want to speak or because of your personality, you do not tend to speak in front of the whole class yet was forced to during critique. On one hand, this mask is a choice that you did to prevent from being forced speaking, on the other hand, it is also forcing you to keep quiet as you have to bite it to hold the mask. Therefore, in a larger scale, this mask can also be viewed as a protesting tool refusing the forced communication.

description.text:
This is a toolholder for the Denford range of CNC Routers.
It will hold the recomended tooling set and an engraving tool.
Incorporated into the DXF for the lid is a depth guage for setting the amount of tool protruding from the spindle nut and making it easier to run programs with tool changes.

The lid is designed to be laser cut from 3mm acrylic, other parts are 3D printed and M3 screws hold the tool holder in the case.

title: Prototype differential for the end effector interface of a robotic arm

description.text:
This mechanism allows 2 degrees of freedom by driving either side in the same or opposite direction, In addition to the 2 DOF it operates smoothly and can withstand moderate loads <10 ibs.   
I manipulated bevel gear files that I got off the internet to create this hands on mechanical design aid. It is really helpful for showing how differentials work.

Print out
2x Bevel1
1x Bevel2
1x Diff support I reemed out the holes in Bevel1 and Bevel2 to .5" then used .5" threaded rod to hold the two bevel1 gears together with the diff support in between them.
then I used a .5" cap screw to mount the Bevel2 gear onto the Diff support.( this screw should fit snug).

comments.text: I have been looking to buy a set of gears as in picture,can anyone help,Prototype differential for the end effector interface of a robotic arm.Can someone please help me out,straight bevel gears between 60 and 75mm outside diameter,just want the gears don't care about colour,bore size,number of teeth or anything else,just the gears,six of or two sets as in picture,thanks
comments.author: soreton

comments.text:
do you still need the gears?
Are you talking about needing them printed?
comments.author: soreton

comments.text: Thank you so much. These gears saved me alot of time on a project im working on at home. They also scaled down well. Thanks again.
comments.author: printerpimp

comments.text: Maybe I'm missing the point...why on the parallel shafts linked together?  I thought a differential will transfer opposite motion from one shaft to another, parallel shaft.
comments.author: MadMoe

comments.text: The point is to allow two independently controlled motors/servos to effectively "share"  torque delivered to the output (the gear with the arrow drawn on it).
comments.author: MadMoe

title: Mauler 180 - FPV Quadcopter w/ Threaded Camera Mount

description.text:
I wanted to design my own quadcopter just for the fun of it and here is what I've come up with, it's nothing special but it is strong, fairly light and flies great. It's a 180mm frame that will accept 1306 and 1806 motors and 4" props (220X version will be done in a day or so) and is designed with a bit of motor protection by extending the ends of the arms out slightly. The camera bracket is threaded with m3 holes to eliminate the need for front standoffs and works with the HS1177 camera. The bracket is 30mm tall so you would need 6 - 30mm standoffs. The Frame and top plate have a bevel on all of the edges, I will post another version without the beveled edges for those who want it.

The bottom frame weighs 66.4 grams printed with 70% infill.
The top plate weighs 15 grams printed with 50% infill.
The camera bracket weighs 5.9 grams printed with 30% infill.

The total weight of the frame, top plate and camera bracket is 87.3 grams.

The AUW (no battery) with the following electronics is 272.1 grams.

XRacer F303 Flight Controller
Armattan Simple PDB
Pololu 5v regulator
Little Bee 20a ESCs
DYS BX1806-2300kv motors
LemonRx Spektrum Satellite Rx
Aomway 200mw VTx
HobbyKing E-OSD
HS1177 FPV camera

Suggested batteries would be from 1000mAh to 1500mAh.

Please let me know what you think. Thank you.

Updated - April 27, 2016: Added a version of the frame and top plate without any beveled edges. (Mauler_No_BevelV4 and Top_Plate_No_BevelV2.3)

Updated - May 5, 2016: Added a frame that will accept 220x motors. Slight changes to the frame include: Widened center braces, removed .5mm of material from the front and rear flat sections of the frame and added .5mm to the center section.

Updated - June 7, 2016: Mauler_BevelV5.stl - Added some material on the inside corners of the 3 sections (front, mid and rear) to strengthen the frame a little. moved the front/rear mounting slots closer together to better accommodate the stock HS1177 camera's metal mounting bracket.

Updated - June 7, 2016: Mauler_BevelV5-M3_Holes.stl - Added a second version that has 3mm mounting holes for some 1806 motors.

Like my stuff? Buy me a beer. Donations are accepted and greatly appreciated.

Paypal: [email protected]

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

Please see the description

Notes:

This was printed with Esun PLA+.

comments.author: fennikin909

comments.text: Decent design. The 3D print won't stand up to many high-speed crashes, unfortunately. If you plan to fly faster than a grandma, I suggest you get it cut from carbon fiber. You'll spend less time waiting for the frame to reprint.
comments.author: anansi22

comments.text:
Thank you , great design.
In PETG it is incredible strong!
comments.author: thooijer

comments.text: Found some awesome ABS for 3D quad printing. Runs at a higher temperature but the prints are solid as a rock with excellent layer adhesion due to the higher temps. Very difficult to snap a print. Try MG Chemicals ABS - the neon runs as high as 263 to make it extrude correctly. I think finding the right filament and temp settings can make a 3D printed frame viable. My previous 180 snapped after clipping a tree. It was light and fast but once it snapped I saw that the inside was not melted together well.

description.text:
The BigBox is a no-compromises, high specification 3D printer. It combines immense print resolution, huge print volume and an extrusion system capable of almost every material on the market. Presented in a neat, clutter free package with an easy to use toolchain, BigBox offers great quality at an even greater price.

Version 1.1 (includes previous STL files for older versions).

Download STL.zip for printable parts.

Join in at E3D's Forum | http://forum.e3d-online.com/

Firmware | https://github.com/BigBox3D

Build Manual | http://wiki.e3d-online.com/wiki/BigBox_Build_Manual

Be sure to check through Greg's Thingiverse for BigBox mods | GregoryHolloway.

Have you made modifications to your BigBox which you want to share? Create a Remix and it will be linked directly from this page for others to see | Add A Remix.

Printer:

E3D BigBox

No

title: little bit of help from thingverse experts out there

description.text: being new to cad designing im asking is someone can help me with my file. Im using google sketchup and i cant figure out how to make cones work on my progect. if someone has the time can you look at my file and replace the circles i made with cones 1mm tall and 2.4 mm wide. Thanks in Advance

comments.text: My version of sketchup is not new enough to make the changes for you.  However, the cone process is pretty easy, in this case.  First, make a circle to the diameter that you need ( i think it was 2.4 mm).  Second, drag the circle to the desired height of 1mm.  Step 3, select the circle at the end of the newly created cylinder.  View the properties.  In the properties dialog box where it shows the radius, adjust the value to as small or large as you need it to be.  Remember though that there will be a minimum limit, of I think .3mm (i think - regardless, there is a printed minimum so that is a good value to use anyway).

passend für:
https://www.conrad.de/de/universal-gehaeuse-191-x-110-x-61-abs-licht-grau-ral-7035-hammond-electronics-boxe-1-st-522641.html

This is intended to mount bearings like: https://sdp-si.com/eStore/..%5Css%5CPDF%5C80505055.pdf Just like: thingiverse.com/thing:13229 they were made to work with: thingiverse.com/thing:13228 Tested for fit, goes together like it was made to. :) I've just uploaded a second version in which the ID is .6mm larger - this version should require less sanding to fit. :)

Note: These images do not include washers, I just tossed this together quickly to verify that it fits, you'll want to include washers on the motor.
Version 2 - the most recent upload has more verticies in the circle in an attempt to correct a bumpiness problem encountered by those printed edges at 60+ mm/sec
Version 2 - slotted - has a little bit of wiggle room around the bolts

One of my friends had an issue that his IKEA drawers were trying to kill him. The smooth closing and push ejector springy things that he had installed kept getting loose and sly out and hit him or just disappear in to the cabinet.  
So he asked if I knew where he could buy something to hold them in place....   I didn't know, so i made a very simple holder that fits over the spring holder and stops it from going anywhere.  
He has reported that it works like a charm... and i can report that they are very easy to print, even in batches as shown in the picture.  
Remember to use short screws, and do not tighten the screws too hard.  
And an apology to Makerbot for not buying YOUR Makerbot Replicator Dual...  but i also have one of your printers :-)   If you need to know more about the Flashforge one i have, let me know.

title: CR-7 Z Axis End Cap with Rod Guide (V-Rail system)

description.text:
An end cap and rod guide for taller CR-7 printers to stop the rod being accidentally knocked or bent.

NOTE: I'd recommend printing at 99% scale or 99.X% to account for discrepancies in plastic extrusion.

Slots into the V rail system used by these printers.

2 Versions:

Without chimney: My Z rod protrudes above the guide rail so there is no need for a reach down chimney piece

With chimney: Opposite of above, if your Z rod doesn't protrude all the way up to the top, the chimney serves to contain it

description.text:
You need also 4 mm pipe. Use Chupa Chups lollipop stick :-)

Here are two versions, normal is about 40 mm, long is about 53 mm.

I have printed the lower part from FLEX-material. It is not slippery, and it works as a shock absorber.

Me and a friend found that having to many N64 games is fun but messy...
So we designed this nice N64 game holder. It holds six games and the label is readable on them all.

For anyone that has already downloaded it, the file "Fack.stl" is an older version, we got them mixed up!!! It will fit but it's a much worse fit. That file is deleted and we have added a new file that is the correct one!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 for fast 0.1 for better fitt.

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Cura is used as slicer.
I use a 0.3mm nozzle.
50mm/s feed rate.
Fan on from 0.5mm hight.

Depending on your printer and such, there might be some sanding involved to get a good fit to the parts. It is designed to be a tight fit and we have noticed that some printers have a hard time printing tight with good precision.
Me and Halvzeri are talking on how we can solve this for a next update.But for now, 600gritt sandpaper is a good help to get them to fit.

Fixing a single screw in the center of the holder.
This allows you to automatically align the site even if the screw holes are drilled not sure. Alignment works well if the distance between the parallel-hole slightly smaller (1-2mm), the distances between the shafts. During this process, simply turn on a slight angle, and will remain horizontal. Works well when worn on the three LM8UU, a little worse when mounting on 4 LM8UU. Worse still works if the distance between the parallel holes larger distance between the shafts, cell alignments will occur due to the deviation from the horizontal position.
Convenient to install the clamp groove width of 3.5 mm.
The minimum height above the platform rolls for this method of attachment Lm8uu.

For fixing screws are needed M3 flat head.
  • Print 3 or 4 the holder.
  • Install the screws.
  • Prior to the installation LM8UU, cap screws to attach the plastic parts. Otherwise it will be difficult to establish.
  • Set LM8UU.
  • Assemble platform.
Tricorder split into parts.

title: Prusa i3 E3D direct extruder holder sideways

description.text:
I use a direct extruder with geared stepper which has two M4 mount holes with 50 mm distance. The x-carriage on my prusa i3 has 6 M3 mount holes.
I have the parts from a friend and i will link them here, if i found out, what items they are.

As i found no suitable adapter here and want the stepper axis in x-direction, i designed here my first part, that i now want to share.
It is designed to be printed on the side with the triangles (rotate y -90 deg in slic3r) so there won't be any overhang.

Please comment if anything essential is missing in my description.

description.text: I have this unique ability to NOT lose my glasses (knock on wood). As a consequence I've got glasses all over the house and they need a home lest they get all scratched up or lost. Thus it was off to the modeling software and here's what I came up with. I printed a couple of these and I'm good to go. Holds up to 4 pairs of glasses. It's very sturdy and each bay will hold even largish sunglasses.

Flashforge Creator Pro

No

No

100

10%

comments.text: I have a unique ability to lose glasses lol. (Really not a laughing matter) any suggestions.
comments.author: Upscale

comments.text: Well in my case I just buy really expensive ones.  I hear that it may have the opposite effect for some people though.  At least if you print this you'll see an empty spot and know they're lost ;)
